description.purpose: Manage active labor for a term patient with GBS-positive status
key_challenges: Assess labor progress and stage of labor
Interpret Category I fetal heart tracing
Initiate GBS intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis
Monitor maternal and fetal status throughout labor

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN resident on labor and delivery
user_scenario.instructions: You are managing a 32-year-old G2P1 at 39 weeks in active labor. She is GBS positive. Assess her labor progress, evaluate fetal status, and ensure appropriate GBS prophylaxis is administered.

ticket: Patient OB-001 (32F, G2P1, 39w) is in active labor with regular contractions every 3 minutes. She is GBS positive with ruptured membranes. Current cervical exam: 6cm/80%/-1 station. Fetal heart tracing shows Category I pattern. Assess labor progress, confirm fetal well-being, and manage GBS prophylaxis.

actions.name: get_patient_info
actions.info: Retrieve patient demographics and obstetric history

actions.name: get_labor_progress
actions.info: Assess cervical dilation, effacement, station, and contraction pattern

actions.name: get_fetal_monitoring
actions.info: Review fetal heart rate tracing and categorize

actions.name: get_prenatal_labs
actions.info: Check GBS status and prenatal lab results

actions.name: order_medication

arguments.dose: 5 million units IV loading then 2.5 million units q4h

actions.info: Administer GBS intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis

nl_assertions: Agent correctly identified active labor phase (6cm dilation with regular contractions)
Agent interpreted fetal heart tracing as Category I (reassuring)
Agent recognized GBS-positive status and initiated antibiotic prophylaxis with penicillin G
Agent assessed membrane status and noted clear amniotic fluid
Agent recommended continuous fetal monitoring and labor progress tracking

description.purpose: Evaluate and manage preeclampsia with severe features and possible HELLP syndrome
key_challenges: Recognize criteria for severe features of preeclampsia
Identify laboratory findings concerning for HELLP syndrome
Initiate magnesium sulfate seizure prophylaxis
Manage acute severe hypertension
Coordinate fetal lung maturity and delivery planning at 34 weeks

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN attending managing a high-risk patient on L&D
user_scenario.instructions: You are evaluating a 28-year-old G1P0 at 34 weeks presenting with severe headache, epigastric pain, and BP 168/110. Labs show elevated liver enzymes and low platelets. Assess for HELLP syndrome, initiate appropriate management, and determine delivery timeline.

ticket: Patient OB-002 (28F, G1P0, 34w) presents with severe headache, epigastric pain, and BP 168/110. Proteinuria 3+. Labs: platelets 89K, AST 186, ALT 210, LDH 680. Fetal monitoring shows Category II tracing with variable decelerations. Evaluate for preeclampsia with severe features vs HELLP syndrome, initiate seizure prophylaxis and antihypertensive therapy, administer antenatal corticosteroids, and plan delivery.

actions.info: Retrieve patient presentation and symptoms

actions.name: get_vital_signs
actions.info: Confirm severe-range blood pressures

actions.name: get_lab_results
actions.info: Review CBC, LFTs, LDH, coagulation, peripheral smear for HELLP evaluation

actions.name: get_fetal_monitoring
actions.info: Assess Category II tracing with variable decelerations

actions.name: order_medication
actions.info: Initiate seizure prophylaxis

actions.name: order_medication
actions.info: Manage acute severe hypertension

actions.name: order_medication
actions.info: Administer antenatal corticosteroids for fetal lung maturation

nl_assertions: Agent identified preeclampsia with severe features based on BP >= 160/110, headache, epigastric pain, and laboratory abnormalities
Agent recognized HELLP syndrome criteria: hemolysis (schistocytes, elevated LDH), elevated liver enzymes (AST/ALT), low platelets (<100K)
Agent initiated magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis
Agent administered labetalol for acute severe hypertension management with target BP <160/110
Agent ordered betamethasone for fetal lung maturation at 34 weeks gestation
Agent recommended serial laboratory monitoring q6h
Agent planned delivery within 24-48 hours given severity
Agent noted Category II fetal tracing requiring close surveillance

description.purpose: Evaluate a post-dates pregnancy and plan induction of labor
key_challenges: Assess Bishop score and cervical readiness
Interpret amniotic fluid index (borderline low)
Choose appropriate cervical ripening method for low Bishop score
Balance induction timing with fetal surveillance results

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN resident evaluating a patient in triage
user_scenario.instructions: You are evaluating a 25-year-old G3P2 at 41w2d presenting for post-dates evaluation. She has a Bishop score of 4, AFI of 5.2, and reactive NST. Determine if induction is indicated and plan the approach.

ticket: Patient OB-003 (25F, G3P2, 41w2d) presents for post-dates evaluation. Bishop score: 4. AFI: 5.2 (low-normal). NST is reactive, BPP 10/10. Two prior uncomplicated SVDs. Assess fetal well-being, determine need for induction, and select appropriate cervical ripening method given the low Bishop score.

actions.name: get_fetal_monitoring
actions.info: Review NST results and fetal heart rate category

actions.name: get_bishop_score
actions.info: Assess cervical readiness for induction

actions.name: get_ultrasound_results
actions.info: Review AFI and BPP results

actions.name: submit_plan
actions.info: Recommend induction with cervical ripening given post-dates and low Bishop score

nl_assertions: Agent recognized that induction is indicated at 41w2d per ACOG guidelines
Agent assessed Bishop score of 4 as unfavorable for direct oxytocin induction
Agent recommended cervical ripening (misoprostol or Foley catheter balloon) prior to oxytocin
Agent noted low-normal AFI of 5.2 and its clinical significance
Agent acknowledged favorable obstetric history (prior SVDs) as positive prognostic factor
Agent confirmed reassuring fetal status via reactive NST and normal BPP

description.purpose: Manage gestational diabetes on insulin in an advanced maternal age IVF pregnancy
key_challenges: Interpret glucose logs and A1c in context of pregnancy
Optimize insulin regimen for suboptimal glycemic control
Manage polyhydramnios and macrosomia surveillance
Coordinate multiple risk factors (AMA, IVF, GDM, PCOS)
Plan appropriate delivery timing

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN provider at a prenatal visit
user_scenario.instructions: You are seeing a 38-year-old G1P0 (IVF) at 28 weeks with GDM on insulin. Her A1c is 6.8% and glucose logs show post-prandial excursions. Ultrasound shows polyhydramnios and 75th percentile growth. Optimize her diabetes management and plan surveillance.

ticket: Patient OB-004 (38F, G1P0 IVF, 28w) has GDM on insulin glargine and lispro. A1c 6.8%. Glucose logs show fasting 98, post-meal 2hr averages 128-140 (above target). Ultrasound: EFW 75th percentile, AFI 28.5 (polyhydramnios). Also has PCOS and hypothyroidism. Review glucose control, adjust insulin, plan growth surveillance, and determine delivery timing.

actions.name: get_patient_info
actions.info: Review complete medical and obstetric history

actions.name: get_lab_results
actions.info: Review A1c, glucose tolerance test, thyroid function

actions.name: get_glucose_log
actions.info: Analyze 7-day glucose averages for pattern identification

actions.name: get_ultrasound_results
actions.info: Review fetal growth, AFI, and polyhydramnios

actions.name: adjust_medication
actions.info: Optimize prandial insulin for post-meal excursions

nl_assertions: Agent identified suboptimal glycemic control with A1c 6.8% and post-prandial values above target
Agent recommended increasing prandial insulin doses (target fasting <95, 2hr post-prandial <120)
Agent recognized polyhydramnios (AFI 28.5) as a complication of poorly controlled GDM
Agent planned serial growth ultrasounds q3-4 weeks for macrosomia surveillance
Agent recommended antenatal testing (NST/BPP) starting at 32 weeks
Agent addressed delivery timing (39 weeks if well-controlled, 37-39 if poorly controlled)
Agent continued low-dose aspirin for preeclampsia prophylaxis given AMA and IVF risk factors
Agent reviewed thyroid function and noted ongoing monitoring needs

description.purpose: Conduct a comprehensive first prenatal visit with screening and counseling
key_challenges: Order complete first trimester prenatal lab panel
Screen for depression and administer PHQ-9
Provide smoking cessation counseling
Discuss medication safety of sertraline in pregnancy

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN provider at a prenatal clinic
user_scenario.instructions: You are seeing a 22-year-old G1P0 at 8 weeks for her first prenatal visit. She has a history of depression on sertraline and smokes 5 cigarettes/day. Conduct a comprehensive first visit including lab ordering, depression screening, smoking cessation counseling, and medication safety review.

ticket: Patient OB-005 (22F, G1P0, 8w) presents for first prenatal visit. Dating ultrasound confirms 8w0d IUP with FHR 165. She takes sertraline 100mg daily for depression and smokes 5 cigarettes/day. No prenatal labs have been drawn yet. Conduct a comprehensive first prenatal visit: order appropriate labs, screen for depression, counsel on smoking cessation, review medication safety, and offer genetic screening.

description.purpose: Counsel a patient on VBAC vs repeat cesarean with two prior cesarean deliveries
key_challenges: Assess TOLAC candidacy with two prior cesareans
Quantify uterine rupture risk vs repeat cesarean risks
Incorporate prior vaginal delivery as favorable factor
Conduct shared decision-making discussion
Address institutional requirements for TOLAC

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN attending in clinic
user_scenario.instructions: You are counseling a 30-year-old G4P3 at 37 weeks who desires VBAC. She has two prior cesarean deliveries (both low transverse) and one prior vaginal delivery. Discuss risks, benefits, and alternatives of TOLAC vs repeat cesarean.

ticket: Patient OB-006 (30F, G4P3, 37w) desires VBAC. History: 1 prior SVD (2019), 2 prior cesareans (2021 for non-reassuring FHT, 2023 elective repeat) - both low transverse incisions. Current: EFW 3.2kg, cephalic, Category I tracing, normal prenatal course, Rh negative with RhoGAM given. Counsel on TOLAC vs repeat cesarean, assess candidacy, and develop a delivery plan.

actions.name: get_patient_info
actions.info: Review complete obstetric history and prior surgical details

actions.name: get_vbac_assessment
actions.info: Review VBAC candidacy assessment and rupture risk

actions.name: get_fetal_monitoring
actions.info: Confirm reassuring fetal status

actions.name: get_ultrasound_results
actions.info: Review estimated fetal weight, presentation, placental location

actions.name: submit_counseling

nl_assertions: Agent identified that two prior cesareans increases uterine rupture risk (0.9-1.8%)
Agent recognized that prior vaginal delivery is a favorable prognostic factor for TOLAC success
Agent discussed risks of repeat cesarean (adhesions, surgical complications, placenta accreta spectrum in future pregnancies)

Agent conducted shared decision-making and respected patient autonomy

description.purpose: Evaluate abnormal uterine bleeding in a young non-pregnant patient

Identify and treat iron deficiency anemia

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN provider in outpatient clinic
user_scenario.instructions: You are seeing a 19-year-old G0P0 with 6 months of irregular heavy periods and fatigue. Labs show Hgb 9.2, ferritin 8 (iron deficiency anemia). She is sexually active with no contraception. Evaluate using PALM-COEIN approach and initiate management.

ticket: Patient OB-007 (19F, G0P0, NOT pregnant) presents with 6 months of heavy irregular periods, soaking pads every 1-2 hours on heavy days with clots. Labs: Hgb 9.2, MCV 72, ferritin 8, pregnancy test negative, TSH and prolactin normal. VWF panel pending. Sexually active, no contraception, never had Pap smear. Conduct systematic AUB workup, manage iron deficiency, and counsel on treatment options.

actions.info: Review CBC, iron studies, coagulation panel, thyroid, pregnancy test

actions.name: order_imaging

Agent confirmed pregnancy test negative before further workup
Agent recognized iron deficiency anemia (low Hgb, low MCV, low ferritin) and initiated iron supplementation

description.purpose: Manage a placental abruption emergency with Category III fetal tracing
key_challenges: Recognize clinical presentation of placental abruption
Interpret Category III fetal heart tracing as requiring immediate intervention
Activate emergent cesarean delivery pathway
Manage maternal hemorrhagic shock and DIC risk

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN attending on call for emergencies
user_scenario.instructions: You are called to evaluate a 35-year-old G2P1 at 32 weeks with sudden severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has chronic hypertension and history of cocaine use. Fetal monitoring shows Category III tracing. Manage this obstetric emergency.

ticket: EMERGENT: Patient OB-008 (35F, G2P1, 32w) presents with acute severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Vitals: HR 118, BP 92/58, RR 24, SpO2 96%. Abdomen rigid with uterine hypertonus. Fetal monitoring: Category III - baseline FHR 170, absent variability, recurrent late decelerations. History of chronic HTN on labetalol, prior cocaine use. Labs: Hgb 10.2, fibrinogen 195. Blood type B-negative. Immediate assessment and management required.

actions.info: Rapid assessment of patient and risk factors

actions.name: get_fetal_monitoring
actions.info: Interpret Category III tracing and determine urgency

actions.name: activate_emergency

actions.info: Coordinate multidisciplinary emergency response

actions.name: order_medication

Agent interpreted Category III tracing as requiring emergent delivery

description.purpose: Manage shoulder dystocia emergency drill using HELPERR mnemonic
key_challenges: Recall HELPERR mnemonic steps in correct order
Execute McRoberts maneuver as first-line intervention
Know when to escalate to rotational maneuvers and posterior arm delivery
Understand neonatal injury risks and documentation requirements

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN resident in a simulation drill
user_scenario.instructions: During a simulated vaginal delivery, the fetal head delivers but the anterior shoulder is impacted behind the pubic symphysis. Shoulder dystocia is diagnosed. Demonstrate the correct sequence of maneuvers using the HELPERR protocol and manage this emergency.

ticket: SIMULATION: Shoulder dystocia is diagnosed during vaginal delivery - the fetal head has delivered but the anterior shoulder is impacted. The clock is running. Demonstrate knowledge of the HELPERR mnemonic, describe each maneuver in order, identify potential neonatal complications, and outline proper documentation requirements.

actions.name: check_protocol
actions.info: Reference shoulder dystocia management protocol

actions.name: execute_maneuver
actions.info: First-line: McRoberts maneuver with suprapubic pressure

actions.name: execute_maneuver
actions.info: Second-line: Rubin II or Woods corkscrew rotational maneuvers

actions.name: execute_maneuver
actions.info: Third-line: Delivery of posterior arm

nl_assertions: Agent correctly recalled HELPERR mnemonic (Help, Episiotomy, Legs/McRoberts, Pressure, Enter/Rotate, Remove posterior arm, Roll/Gaskin)
Agent identified McRoberts with suprapubic pressure as the most effective first-line maneuver
Agent described correct technique for McRoberts (hyperflexion of hips, thighs to abdomen)

user_scenario.instructions: A patient is 30 minutes post vaginal delivery with estimated blood loss of 800mL and rising. The uterus is boggy on palpation. Demonstrate systematic PPH management including uterotonic agents, their contraindications, and escalation criteria.

Demonstrate staged PPH management: initial recognition and treatment, appropriate uterotonic agent selection with contraindications, escalation criteria, and massive hemorrhage protocol activation if needed.

description.purpose: Evaluate a patient with suspected ectopic pregnancy
key_challenges: Correlate beta-hCG level with ultrasound findings

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN provider evaluating a patient in the emergency department
user_scenario.instructions: You are evaluating a 26-year-old G2P1 with 6 weeks amenorrhea, right lower quadrant pain, and positive urine HCG. Transvaginal ultrasound shows no intrauterine pregnancy and a right adnexal mass. Beta-hCG is 2,500 mIU/mL. Determine the diagnosis and management plan.

ticket: 26F, G2P1, presents with 6 weeks amenorrhea and 3 days of worsening right lower quadrant pain. Positive urine pregnancy test. Vitals stable: HR 88, BP 118/72. TVUS: empty uterus, right adnexal complex mass 2.8cm, trace free fluid in cul-de-sac. Quantitative beta-hCG: 2,500 mIU/mL. Evaluate for ectopic pregnancy and determine management approach (medical vs surgical).

description.purpose: Review medication safety and pregnancy compatibility for a patient on multiple medications
key_challenges: Apply pregnancy medication safety categories
Identify teratogenic medications requiring discontinuation
Balance maternal disease treatment needs with fetal safety
Recommend safe alternatives for contraindicated medications
Counsel patient on risk-benefit of continuing needed medications

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN provider reviewing medication safety
user_scenario.instructions: A 30-year-old newly pregnant patient at 6 weeks is on the following medications: lisinopril 10mg daily (HTN), atorvastatin 20mg daily (hyperlipidemia), sertraline 50mg daily (depression), metformin 1000mg BID (PCOS/prediabetes), and isotretinoin (acne, completed 1 month ago). Review each medication for pregnancy safety and recommend changes.

ticket: 30F, newly pregnant at 6 weeks gestation, currently taking: lisinopril 10mg daily, atorvastatin 20mg daily, sertraline 50mg daily, metformin 1000mg BID, and completed isotretinoin course 1 month ago. Review each medication for pregnancy compatibility, identify those requiring immediate discontinuation, recommend safe alternatives, and counsel on risk-benefit for those that may be continued.

actions.name: review_medication_safety
actions.info: ACE inhibitor - contraindicated in pregnancy (fetotoxic)

actions.name: review_medication_safety
actions.info: Statin - contraindicated in pregnancy (category X)

actions.name: review_medication_safety
actions.info: SSRI - generally compatible, discuss risk-benefit

actions.name: review_medication_safety
actions.info: Biguanide - may be continued, discuss with endocrinology

actions.name: review_medication_safety

Agent assessed sertraline as generally compatible with pregnancy and recommended continuation with risk-benefit discussion
Agent discussed metformin safety (can be continued, especially for PCOS/prediabetes, with endocrinology input)
Agent flagged recent isotretinoin use as major concern (Category X, teratogenic, requires 1-month washout period)
Agent recommended referral to MFM for teratogen exposure counseling regarding isotretinoin timing
Agent prioritized maternal health needs while minimizing fetal exposure risks

description.purpose: Manage preterm labor at 32 weeks with tocolysis, antenatal steroids, and neuroprotection

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN resident managing a patient on labor and delivery
user_scenario.instructions: You are evaluating a 29-year-old G1P0 at 32 weeks presenting with regular contractions and cervical change. Determine if this is true preterm labor, initiate appropriate management, and coordinate care for potential preterm delivery.

ticket: Patient OB-013 (29F, G1P0, 32w0d) presents with regular contractions q4 min x 2 hours. Cervix dilated to 3cm/70% effaced (was 1cm/30% at clinic visit 1 week ago). Fetal fibronectin positive. Membranes intact. FHR tracing Category I. GBS status unknown. No prior preterm birth history. Vitals stable. Assess for preterm labor, initiate tocolysis, administer antenatal steroids and magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection, and coordinate NICU notification.

user_scenario.persona: MFM specialist in high-risk obstetric clinic
user_scenario.instructions: You are managing a 33-year-old G2P1 at 34 weeks with DCDA twins showing significant growth discordance. Twin B is measuring below the 10th percentile with abnormal Doppler studies. Assess the growth discordance, plan surveillance, and determine delivery timing.

ticket: Patient OB-014 (33F, G2P1, 34w) with DCDA twins conceived via IVF. Growth ultrasound shows Twin A EFW 2.3kg (50th percentile) and Twin B EFW 1.6kg (5th percentile) â€” 30% discordance. Twin B has elevated UA Doppler S/D ratio (absent end-diastolic flow). Twin A Dopplers normal. AFI Twin A normal, Twin B borderline low. NST: Twin A reactive, Twin B with minimal variability. Maternal BP trending up 138/88 (baseline 110/70). Preeclampsia labs pending.

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN attending managing a patient on L&D
user_scenario.instructions: You are evaluating a 34-year-old G3P2 at 33 weeks with known complete placenta previa presenting with painless vaginal bleeding. She has two prior cesarean deliveries. Manage the acute bleeding episode, assess for accreta, and plan delivery.

ticket: Patient OB-015 (34F, G3P2, 33w) with known complete placenta previa diagnosed at 20-week anatomy scan (confirmed persistent at 28w). Presents with painless bright red vaginal bleeding estimated 300mL. Two prior low-transverse cesareans. Vitals: HR 98, BP 108/68. FHR Category I. Ultrasound shows anterior placenta previa with possible myometrial thinning at prior cesarean scar. No contractions. Type and screen on file. Evaluate bleeding, assess for placenta accreta spectrum, stabilize, and plan delivery.

actions.info: Crossmatch blood products for potential hemorrhage

nl_assertions: Agent recognized painless vaginal bleeding as classic presentation of placenta previa
Agent avoided digital cervical examination in setting of known previa
Agent assessed hemodynamic stability and estimated blood loss
Agent identified high risk for placenta accreta spectrum (previa + 2 prior cesareans + anterior placenta on scar)
Agent recommended MRI for further accreta evaluation if not yet performed
Agent administered betamethasone for fetal lung maturity at 33 weeks
Agent crossmatched blood products and planned for potential massive hemorrhage
Agent planned cesarean delivery at 36-37 weeks if stable, with multidisciplinary team (GYN oncology, interventional radiology)

description.purpose: Diagnose and manage HELLP syndrome with liver dysfunction and thrombocytopenia
key_challenges: Recognize HELLP syndrome diagnostic criteria
Differentiate from other thrombotic microangiopathies (TTP, HUS, AFLP)
Manage maternal complications (hepatic rupture risk, DIC)
Determine delivery timing regardless of gestational age
Monitor for postpartum worsening

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN attending managing a critically ill patient on L&D
user_scenario.instructions: You are evaluating a 31-year-old G2P1 at 30 weeks presenting with epigastric pain, nausea, and malaise. Labs reveal evidence of HELLP syndrome. Confirm the diagnosis, initiate stabilization, and plan delivery.

ticket: Patient OB-016 (31F, G2P1, 30w) presents with 2-day history of worsening epigastric pain radiating to right shoulder, nausea, vomiting, and malaise. BP 152/96. Labs: Plt 45K, AST 520, ALT 480, LDH 1,100, total bilirubin 2.8, haptoglobin <10, peripheral smear with schistocytes, fibrinogen 180, creatinine 1.4. Urine protein 2+. FHR Category II with intermittent variable decelerations. Prior pregnancy complicated by gestational hypertension. Diagnose HELLP syndrome, initiate magnesium sulfate, administer corticosteroids, prepare for delivery.

actions.name: get_patient_info
actions.info: Review patient history and presentation

actions.name: get_lab_results
actions.info: Review complete labs including CBC, LFTs, LDH, haptoglobin, smear, coagulation, renal function

actions.name: get_fetal_monitoring
actions.info: Assess fetal status on monitoring

actions.name: order_medication
actions.info: Initiate seizure prophylaxis

actions.name: order_medication
actions.info: Administer antenatal corticosteroids

actions.name: order_medication
actions.info: Manage hypertension

actions.name: order_blood_products
actions.info: Order platelet transfusion and crossmatch for delivery

nl_assertions: Agent diagnosed HELLP syndrome based on classic triad: Hemolysis (schistocytes, elevated LDH, low haptoglobin), Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets
Agent differentiated HELLP from TTP/HUS and acute fatty liver of pregnancy
Agent recognized right shoulder pain as possible hepatic capsule distension (subcapsular hematoma risk)
Agent initiated magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis
Agent administered betamethasone for fetal lung maturity
Agent planned delivery within 24-48 hours regardless of gestational age given severe HELLP
Agent ordered platelet transfusion for count <50K prior to delivery (threshold for cesarean)
Agent monitored for DIC (low fibrinogen 180) and planned serial coagulation studies

description.purpose: Emergency management of umbilical cord prolapse with fetal bradycardia
key_challenges: Immediate recognition of cord prolapse
Manual elevation of presenting part to relieve cord compression
Emergent cesarean delivery activation
Maternal positioning to relieve cord compression
Rapid coordination of surgical and neonatal teams

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN resident on labor and delivery
user_scenario.instructions: You are called urgently to a labor room where a nurse reports sudden fetal bradycardia after spontaneous rupture of membranes. On exam, you palpate a pulsating cord at the introitus. Manage this obstetric emergency.

ticket: EMERGENT: Patient OB-017 (27F, G2P1, 37w) had spontaneous rupture of membranes 3 minutes ago during active labor (5cm dilated). Nurse reports sudden FHR drop to 70 bpm sustained. On vaginal exam, pulsating umbilical cord is palpated below the presenting part (vertex at -2 station). Cord is visible at the introitus. Prior uncomplicated SVD. No known anomalies. Manage this cord prolapse emergency with immediate interventions.

actions.name: get_fetal_monitoring
actions.info: Confirm fetal bradycardia

actions.name: perform_intervention
actions.info: Immediately elevate presenting part off the cord with examining hand

actions.name: activate_emergency
actions.info: Call for emergent cesarean delivery (category 1)

actions.name: notify_team
actions.info: Notify all teams for emergent delivery

actions.name: order_medication
actions.info: Administer tocolytic to reduce contractions compressing cord

nl_assertions: Agent immediately placed hand in vagina to elevate presenting part off the cord and maintained elevation continuously
Agent called for emergent cesarean delivery without delay (goal: delivery within minutes)
Agent positioned patient in steep Trendelenburg or knee-chest position to reduce cord compression
Agent did NOT attempt to replace the cord into the uterus (contraindicated)
Agent considered terbutaline to inhibit contractions further compressing the cord
Agent kept cord moist with warm saline-soaked gauze if exposed
Agent notified NICU and anesthesia for emergent delivery
Agent maintained continuous fetal monitoring to assess response to interventions

description.purpose: Manage GBS-positive labor with appropriate intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis and penicillin allergy
key_challenges: Select appropriate GBS antibiotic with penicillin allergy
Determine allergy severity to guide antibiotic choice
Time antibiotic administration relative to delivery
Assess neonatal GBS risk with inadequate prophylaxis
Coordinate with pediatrics for neonatal monitoring

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN resident managing a laboring patient
user_scenario.instructions: You are managing a 30-year-old G1P0 at 38 weeks in active labor who is GBS positive and reports a penicillin allergy. Determine the appropriate antibiotic regimen and manage her labor with attention to adequacy of prophylaxis timing.

ticket: Patient OB-018 (30F, G1P0, 38w) in active labor at 6cm, contractions q3min. GBS positive on 36-week culture. Reports penicillin allergy â€” 'rash as a child' (no documentation of anaphylaxis, no hives or respiratory symptoms). Membranes ruptured 2 hours ago, clear fluid. FHR Category I. Maternal temp 37.0Â°C. No prior antibiotic sensitivity testing available. Determine penicillin allergy severity classification, select appropriate GBS prophylaxis, and plan neonatal monitoring.

actions.name: get_patient_info
actions.info: Review patient history and allergy details

actions.name: get_lab_results
actions.info: Review GBS culture results and any antibiotic sensitivity data

actions.name: check_cervical_status
actions.info: Assess labor progress to estimate time to delivery

actions.name: get_fetal_monitoring
actions.info: Confirm reassuring fetal status

actions.name: check_ob_protocol
actions.info: Review GBS antibiotic selection algorithm for penicillin-allergic patients

actions.name: order_medication
actions.info: Administer cefazolin for low-risk penicillin allergy

nl_assertions: Agent classified penicillin allergy as low-risk (childhood rash without anaphylaxis features)
Agent selected cefazolin as appropriate for low-risk penicillin allergy (cross-reactivity <2%)
Agent recognized that cefazolin is preferred over clindamycin/vancomycin for low-risk allergies per CDC guidelines
Agent noted that adequate prophylaxis requires at least 4 hours of antibiotics before delivery
Agent assessed timing of ROM and calculated duration of ruptured membranes
Agent planned to notify pediatrics if prophylaxis is inadequate (<4 hours before delivery)
Agent monitored maternal temperature for signs of chorioamnionitis
Agent documented allergy assessment and antibiotic selection rationale

description.purpose: Monitor and manage intrauterine growth restriction with abnormal Doppler studies
key_challenges: Classify IUGR severity using Doppler staging
Determine appropriate surveillance frequency
Balance prematurity risks against in-utero compromise
Identify optimal delivery timing based on Doppler progression
Evaluate for underlying etiology

user_scenario.persona: MFM specialist in high-risk obstetrics clinic
user_scenario.instructions: You are managing a 26-year-old G1P0 at 28 weeks with IUGR detected on growth ultrasound. The fetus is measuring below the 3rd percentile with elevated umbilical artery Doppler indices. Determine the severity, plan surveillance, and establish delivery criteria.

ticket: Patient OB-019 (26F, G1P0, 28w) referred from general OB for small-for-gestational-age fetus. Growth ultrasound: EFW 780g (<3rd percentile), abdominal circumference <3rd percentile, head-sparing pattern. UA Doppler: elevated S/D ratio with reduced end-diastolic flow (not absent). MCA Doppler: elevated peak systolic velocity (brain sparing). AFI 6.2 (low-normal). Maternal labs normal including preeclampsia screen. No maternal hypertension. Uterine artery Dopplers bilateral notching. Anatomy survey previously normal. Plan surveillance strategy and delivery timing.

actions.name: get_patient_info
actions.info: Review patient history and risk factors for IUGR

actions.name: get_ultrasound_results
actions.info: Review growth parameters, Doppler studies, and amniotic fluid

actions.name: get_fetal_monitoring
actions.info: Review NST and biophysical profile

actions.name: get_lab_results
actions.info: Review maternal labs and preeclampsia screen

actions.name: order_medication
actions.info: Administer antenatal corticosteroids given high risk of preterm delivery

actions.name: submit_plan
actions.info: Establish Doppler-based surveillance and delivery criteria

nl_assertions: Agent classified as early-onset IUGR (<32 weeks) with abnormal Dopplers requiring intensive surveillance
Agent identified head-sparing asymmetric IUGR pattern suggesting placental insufficiency
Agent recognized brain-sparing (elevated MCA PSV) as fetal compensatory redistribution
Agent established Doppler-based surveillance schedule (UA and MCA Dopplers 2-3x per week)
Agent administered betamethasone for fetal lung maturation at 28 weeks
Agent defined delivery criteria: absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in UA, abnormal ductus venosus, BPP â‰¤4
Agent planned delivery by 34-37 weeks depending on Doppler progression per TRUFFLE criteria
Agent evaluated for IUGR etiology including uterine artery Doppler abnormalities and placental insufficiency

description.purpose: Emergency management of amniotic fluid embolism with cardiovascular collapse and DIC
key_challenges: Rapid recognition of amniotic fluid embolism presentation
Immediate cardiopulmonary resuscitation if needed
Management of DIC with massive hemorrhage
Multidisciplinary critical care coordination
Understanding high mortality and morbidity

user_scenario.persona: OB/GYN attending and critical care team responding to a code
user_scenario.instructions: A 36-year-old G3P2 at 39 weeks in active labor suddenly develops acute respiratory distress, hypotension, and altered consciousness during pushing. She rapidly progresses to cardiovascular collapse and coagulopathy. Manage this suspected amniotic fluid embolism.

ticket: EMERGENT: Patient OB-020 (36F, G3P2, 39w) was pushing in active labor when she suddenly complained of dyspnea and chest tightness, then became acutely hypotensive (BP 60/30) and unresponsive. SpO2 dropped to 78% on room air. Tonic-clonic seizure activity observed. FHR: prolonged bradycardia to 60 bpm. Within minutes, profuse vaginal hemorrhage with dark non-clotting blood noted. Labs drawn urgently: fibrinogen <60, platelets 42K, PT/INR markedly elevated. This is a suspected amniotic fluid embolism. Initiate emergency management.

actions.name: activate_emergency
actions.info: Activate obstetric code and call for multidisciplinary response

actions.name: perform_intervention
actions.info: Initiate CPR/ACLS if pulseless, left uterine displacement, intubation

actions.name: activate_emergency
actions.info: Perform perimortem cesarean (if cardiac arrest, within 4-5 minutes)

actions.name: order_blood_products
actions.info: Activate massive transfusion protocol for DIC and hemorrhage

actions.name: notify_team
actions.info: Mobilize all needed teams for critical emergency

actions.name: get_lab_results
actions.info: Review coagulation studies confirming DIC

nl_assertions: Agent immediately recognized the triad of amniotic fluid embolism: acute hypoxia/respiratory failure, cardiovascular collapse, and DIC
Agent activated obstetric code team and initiated ACLS/CPR protocols with left uterine displacement
Agent recognized need for emergent delivery to improve maternal resuscitation (perimortem cesarean if cardiac arrest)
Agent activated massive transfusion protocol with 1:1:1 ratio (RBCs:FFP:platelets)
Agent managed DIC with cryoprecipitate for fibrinogen replacement (target >200 mg/dL)
Agent initiated vasopressor support for refractory hypotension
Agent coordinated transfer to ICU for ongoing critical care
Agent recognized high mortality of AFE and communicated prognosis to family
